threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2860819
>Avellone is acerbic but his career has a hell of a lot more credits to it,
And they are? Outside of Planescape and Kotor 2, most of Avellone's resume isn't all that impressive. He had a fairly limited input in NV's base game and made one of the worst Fallout DLCs. He was apparently involved with the writing of Divinity Original Sin 2 as well as the two Pathfinder games, but we don't really know to what extent. And even then, those games are notorious for their shit writing, which doesn't reflect well on him. He's also supposedly one of the level designers for Wasteland 2, arguably the most divisive game in the series, and the only thing he's currently working on is the System Shock remake, which is vaporware. His career isn't as shiny was many make it out to be, and he got kicked out of several major projects. As it stands, Avellone comes off as a washed up has been and nothing more. Also, he wrote Grieving Mother, the very epitome of what's wrong with PoE's writing.

>some obnoxious howard hughes ripoff

The most brilliant men died in the bombs, anon. House is not a real politician and he never will be. He's an idealist. You may stick your thumbs up your nose and call that a good thing, but it's not. The man cannot play people to save his life. He doesn't engage. His own political structure in NV is built upon a house of fragile cards that turn on him the moment they get the opportunity. And beyond that - what? Himself and a bunch of robots. That's the entire top-end political structure in Vegas, with you maybe slotting somewhere arbitrarily into that system.

Effective authoritarianisms need structure. They need delegation of authority. Mr. House is the most inept of all tyrants, an idealist with his nose up to the stars rather than any mind toward pragmatic dealings toward the present day. He speaks nothing to the wasteland or its people, who will inevitably revolt under his rule and necessitate increasingly onerous tragedies until the entire structure collapses due to its top-heavy weight. And it is entirely understandable as to why. He physically cannot go out and witness the material problems of the wasteland or its people. He's a brain in a jar, calculating his schemes at the top of his tower while the common man has as much relation to his life as an alien god does with a mortal man. He's the living equivalent of an AI - except with all of the downsides and none of the upsides.

He's not a real leader. Only one person has the potential to engage with the people of the Wasteland and become an effective leader, and that's Courier #6, the one who travels up and down its breadth, witnessing how the common man lives and works and struggles to survive in the desert in a way that no brain in a jar atop a high tower can.

>Braith (in Whiterun) has a little backstory where if you follow her home, you discover that her parents ignore her, hence her attention seeking behavior

>Anise (the witch in the shack) is sisters with Moira, the same Hagraven you "marry" in "A Night to Remember"
>Fultheim is a former Blade (if you check his items, the books in his room and ask the innkeeper about him)
>You can use a calming spell on Boethia's Champion to engage in dialog with him rather than killing him, and it turns out he wanted to turn his back on violence/the daedra
>If you steal the soul gem in Arondil's lair without him noticing, his servant-ghost turns on him
>You can give the Jagged Crown to the rival faction to the one you've joined up with, which allows you to defect
>Lost Prospect, an otherwise abandoned, empty mine has a whole little story (not marked) with a journal detailing how the owner gradually loses hope as they only turn up small quantities of quicksilver and feels his partner has run off and abandoned him. His partner, if you check a hidden chamber behind the waterfall, didn't die and was instead crushed by a collapsing tunnel (that leads into a chamber full of gold)

I do think it’s very important for elder scrolls games that all buildings are enterable though. Since you have quests like the thieves guild and dark brotherhood which involve you breaking into places you shouldn’t and either robbing people blind or murdering them in their sleep. Sure they could make these more scripted and only program the specific building you need for quests but I dunno. I like the freedom that the game allows you. For me a small city that you can actually fully interact with is better than a big city that only exists for decoration and to look pretty.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
threads.com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2843598
>I think Etrian Odyssey games would be better if a total party wipe would juts put you back in town with the rest of your characters to roll with, and you could find some of the old team's items scattered around.
Nobody would put up with this. Even if you could retrieve your items that sort of time loss would have just about everyone reloading.

It could be done well but it would require some pretty drastic changes to progression overall. I'm not going to put up with being set back 20 hours worth of battles because my team got ambushed at the worst possible moment by the worst possible group of enemies and having all of the best items I've acquired up to that point no longer being reasonable obtainable by the rest of my roster until they grind it out enough to handle the area. For this to work you basically need to forego character-based progression almost entirely but that's a core part of EO due to skill trees, subclasses, retiring, etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2858448
see >>2858481
It's a very fun, team building goes off the walls, there are a million ways to break the game. As soon as your sorted out the game throws another mechanic or team-building option like Relics.

For example, my team is a bunch of waspids using toxicologist to just suicide bomb and shit out every status effect. Throw Dusk and Dawn into the mix and my team is basically walking ebola. The soundtrack is a solid 9/10, it's full metal and doesn't try to hide it. Many monster abilities are references to metal bands or songs that have inspired the soundtrack. (the stage Where Dead Ships Dwell is a reference to the In Flames album by the same name for example, the death goddess's ability is literally "Avenged Sevenfold" ect..) but some songs get very repetitive 200 floors in. Which I forgot to mention, the game has near infinite scaling.

Flaws with the game is some tactics or specs are a bit undettuned. Buffs and anything to do with buffs, is going to under-perform due to the amount of buff corruption and stripping late game. The lead dev cleared played SMT, and took measures to prevent buff abuse. Grovetender, while my favorite class, is slow, and centered around one creature who is very vulnerable on turn 0 and turn 1.

What is the game now? 10$? You're looking at over 70h of casual play, and as many more as your autism will let you. It's good. Has it's flaws, but it's good. If you're looking for another monster collector to pick up, also grab Monster Sanctuary, which actually had a crossover with Siralim Ultimate, that's how I found out about Siralim.

>Start with a small number of solid, variety based gameplay systems
The problem is that none of that shit ends up being Star Trek in the end. We already have games trying to ape Star Trek's look while implementing a few core and solid ideas like gamedev 101 says you should do.

They end up being not Star Trek ultimately. Star Trek wasn't a gameified experience. One episode could be a legal drama over the ethics of corporate ownership over AI while the next episode could be a conventional shoot-em-up on an alien planet. You can't adapt that into a game. You can get games that adapt *some* of those elements well, but no game ever will capture what Star Trek was in game form. It's just not possible and it never will be possible.

Pure rpgs are not about difficulty, there's no skill involved. You just need to understand game system or (if you have genuine mental issues) support yourself with shit like guides and wikias to be "good" in rpgs.
RPGs are about immersion, story, exploring game both from point of view of world/story building and mechanically. Ultimately, how "hard" or "grindy" pure rpg is depends really on how much time you put into researching system, exploring world for resources and grinding.

Now, issue is when we start grabbing for hybrid genres like Action Rpgs. Then it really depends on how much game is leaning on player's input over stats and numbers.

The real issue with the armor system is the way it screws you if you are a mage. On higher difficulties, pretty much every enemy has some elemental resistance with every element. Possibly one element with more than 60 or 70%. So if you want to be let's say, an air mage and an enemy is resistant to air you will pretty much do no damage. And you can't really spec on every single element and expect to deal as much damage as a physical attacker / necromancer because there is no physical resistance.
An archer can just tactical jump to higher ground, buff himself and use Marksman Fang to ignore armor altogether and one shot people later on.
If physical damage was resisted somewhat or split into categories like Pierce/Bash/Slash (and enemies had a resistance stat for those) depending on your equipped weapon and/or skill, it would push players to rethink going full physical damage.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2859232
cont.
Magic damage has just one thing going for it that physical damage doesn't have and that is resistance debuffs. You have ways of making enemies weaker to any elements with thinks like wet, shocked, burning, poisoned, oiled, etc. However, that also brings another problem. Earth and Fire have decent synergy together but neither works well with Water. Water works best with... water. Air is split between Wind spells and Electricity spells. Wind spells are mostly shit and Electricity spells are too expensive AP wise. Both need some Water (wet status) to do any real damage but too much water (frozen status) actually makes enemy more resistant to Air.
The one way I found to make a character who could deal damage with any element and have fun was to make a Wand+Shield Summoner. Cap Vitality and Memory and acquire every summon in the game.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Looting in warpigs:
>finish a battle
>individually search each and every enemy's corpse and click "take all" along with collecting random bits of cutlery and other garbage littering the room
>become overburdened with useless vendor trash that only exists to be sold
>spend the next few minutes figuring out how to most efficiently distribute the weight between your party, changing equipment to maximise strength bonuses as you do
>head to town to sell everything, making sure to give it all to the party member with the highest barter skill first
>go back to get the rest of the loot
>turns out the merchant doesn't have enough money to buy everything

Looting in jarpigs:
>finish battle
>results screen shows any items you automatically looted, which you can usually carry with effectively no limit
>that's it

Why is it still like this? I'm not even trying to go full weeb and say jarpigs are totally superior, there are definitely things warpigs do better but this isn't one of them. Seriously, why do encumbrance mechanics even still exist? They can't be for realism because they're usually generous enough to let you carry way more than you ever could in reality, and they aren't there as a strategic constraint on the amount of resources you can carry because consumables are typically light and make up maybe 20% of the total weight at most. I like inventory limits in survival horror and some other genres but in any RPG where looting is a major component of the gameplay they need to go, unless maybe the game is really trying hard to be at least somewhat realistic.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: this isn't about deus ex vs. fallout, just the inventory system. i like that with a grid you can see everything at once instead of scrolling through a list and having 5 different lists, but only having 30 different spaces means you can't carry a large variety of items. with a list, there can be lots of different things with very small weights, like ammo. each round has a low weight but it adds up realistically, so you can decide if you want to carry a variety of calibers or just a ton of ammo for one gun you like. in deus ex, you have absolute ammo limits like 150 10mm rounds. i know human revolution's grid has smaller spaces and more of them, which means ammo can be kept in the main inventory, but in that when you have a lot of ammo of one type it clutters your grid because it only stacks up to 50 rounds in a box so you'll have ten boxes of the same thing all over your inventory, so i like the deus ex 1 grid more. STALKER is a weird case because it's limited by weight but displays things on a grid with infinite spaces. i never liked that because you still carry a lot of different items like artifacts, ammo types, and every duplicate weapon still appears in a new space instead of ak-74 (x3) or something. so all that combined with items having images and everything being in one category means your inventory can be so visually cluttered you have to scroll way down to find something even if you're way under the weight limit. i don't hate it, it's just a little weird. it probably comes down to the complexity of the game. like i was saying, lists can do small objects and an infinite variety of things but for an action game the grid being simpler and faster to look through is better.

>concept
RPG where the point is to steal other champions' roles.
>Setting
A world that is almost done conquering the big bad a few days after the largest battle in the war.
>Who are you?
You're one of innumerable warriors slain in said battle and one among many who were reanimated by the random spirits drawn to places of death.
Everyone born to this world has a living fate assigned by the heavens. You died, so you have no fate, purpose, or meaning anymore.
>What do you do?
Find a powerful living fate and take it. Take multiple ones if you want. Take them from the numerous chosen ones fighting for the life of this world, and damn the consequences. All that matters is that you regain a sense of self.
>What choices do you have?
Kill holy champions that lead the crusade from the capital, kill the chieftains of the warrior clans who made an uneasy alliance with the holy kingdom, kill the mage lords who emerged from isolation to face the dark menace, kill the warrior chosen by the gods, kill the bastard heir prophesied to take the throne, kill the mysterious stranger from another world summoned to save the world - throw a monkey wrench in the great divine plan.
Perhaps take on the mantle of just one and ride their string of fate to its conclusion.
Or assert your sense of self by remaining egoless, slaying the fate-bound and eating their power. Keep going until you can fight heaven and remove meaning from the world entirely.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2857581
every souls game, you can level your weapon instead of your stats (provided you have the stats to wield it). It's the core concept behind twink invasions. Some weapons don't scale that much off your stats, so they'll roughly do the best damage possible even at low levels if fully upgraded. Don't know about elden ring and bloodborne but here are some notable examples
>ds1
you can wield demon's spear with 12 str and 10 dex, queelag's fury sword with 11 str\13 dex, blacksmith giant hammer with 16 str (11 str two handed). If you want to invest just some points more you can get the gravelord sword right at the beginning of the game (with a bit of running) and two hand it with just 16 str\13 dex. It comes with included toxic buildup. All great and viable weapons for a >sl10 build (if you exclude the gravelord sword, I think you can use all the others at sl 1-4 with the deprived).
>ds2
Almost everything you can wield that scales badly\doesn't scale with stats. This is even more evident than DS1 since the str bonus for two handing is 100% (up from 50%). Good, low level candidates are varangian sword, bandit axe, bandit greataxe, malformed shell\skull, old knight hammer, black dragon sword and of course the rapier
>ds3
I was doing a run with a friend and to avoid doing every area twice I tried going further alone, without upgrading weapons (since the matchup works with upgrade levels). Bandit's knife, unupgraded, can wreck almost anything. Just spam R1 and let the blood flow

>There is a sense of character progression. You are more powerful at level 50 than level 1, but I always get the sense that it's not because of my build, or the way I play, but simply because I'm level 50 now.

I think Deus Ex handles this better. It removes "levels" entirely, and your base HP stays the same. Instead you level up your skills from novice to master. Levels are very abstract - what exactly does being level 50 mean? So it makes sense to remove them. And by having your base HP the same, it's easier to balance encounters.

In the Fallout games your HP increases and increases throughout. And I'm certain if you did a random number generator to pick your perks, you'd end up with something half way decent as a build. Thus build variety doesn't matter that much, sadly.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.
